noun.description: A typical example or pattern of something; a model.
examples: there is a new paradigm for public art in this country

noun.description: A set of linguistic items that form mutually exclusive choices in particular syntactic roles.
examples: English determiners form a paradigm: we can say “a book” or “his book” but not “a his book.”

noun.description: (in the traditional grammar of Latin, Greek, and other inflected languages) a table of all the inflected forms of a particular verb, noun, or adjective, serving as a model for other words of the same conjugation or declension.

origin: Late 15th century: via late Latin from Greek paradeigma, from paradeiknunai show side by side, from para- beside + deiknunai to show.
